questions.text: Pick the nerve nucleus that underlies the facial colliculus.
questions.solution:
The facial colliculus is present on the floor of the 4th ventricle. It's formed by the looping of facial fibers over the abducens nerve nucleus. Hence, the Facial colliculus overlies the abducens nucleus.

   



Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 1464.e17,410

choices.text: Infection can spread to cavernous sinus from danger area of face via inferior ophthalmic vein

questions.text: Which of these is not true about the cavernous sinus thrombosis:
questions.solution:
The jaw jerk reflex is unaffected in the case of Cavernous Sinus Thrombosis because both the afferent and efferent sensations are carried by the mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve which lies outside of the cavernous sinus.

However, it does lead to loss of sensation around the eye due to the involvement of the ophthalmic branch present in the lateral wall of the sinus. It most commonly spreads through ethmoid sinus and can spread from danger area of face via Inferior ophthalmic vein. 

    


 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 403,404,700,1464.e102

questions.text: What is the Membrana tectoria a continuation of?
questions.solution:
The occipitoaxial ligaments, or Membrana Tectoria, are located inside the spinal canal.
It is considered to be an upward extension of the posterior longitudinal ligament of the vertebral column and is a wide, strong band that covers the dens and its ligaments.

      

From the above image - it's evident that the posterior longitudinal ligament( Lig. longitudinale posterious) continues upwards as Membrana tectoria. 


Reference: https://www.physio-pedia.com/Tectorial_membrane

questions.text: Pick the correct nerve that doesn't pass through the foramen marked in the picture.
questions.solution:
The arrow points towards Foramen Ovale, present in the sphenoid bone.
Contents of Foramen ovale include: Trick- MALE

  • Mandibular Nerve (Sensory and motor branch)
  • Accessory Meningeal Artery
  • Lesser Petrosal Nerve
  • Emissary Vein from Cavernous sinus.
The maxillary nerve instead passes through the Foramen Rotundum(not foramen ovale) present in the base of the greater wing of the sphenoid bone.


 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 566,567,232

questions.text: Which of these is not true about the sphincter urethrae?
questions.solution:
The Internal Urethral Sphincter is located at the Bladder neck, not the Sphincter urethrae.

Sphincter Urethrae
Also known as the External urethral sphincter. 
It's made of striated muscle fibers and hence voluntary. 
Takes origin from ischiopubic rami on each side and is a content of deep perineal space.
Its supplied by the perineal branch of the pudendal nerve. 



Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 1255,1464e.147

questions.text: Which joints' axes move parallel to one another as the foot pronates?
questions.solution:
The talonavicular joint (present along the longitudinal axis) and the calcaneocuboid joint make up the midtarsal joint (present along the oblique axis).
These two axes are comparatively divergent when the subtalar joint is in a neutral position.
However, these two axes become parallel as the subtalar joint pronates, i.e. during the unlocking of the foot.




Reference-: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition Page no  1445-1450

questions.text: A short but high frequency 5 Hz stimulation of perforating substance pathway in the hippocampus would result in
questions.solution:
A short high frequency 5 Hz stimulation of perforating substance pathway in the hippocampus would result in Long-term potentiation. 

Long term potentiation
Long-term potentiation is a fast-developing and prolonged enhancement of the postsynaptic potential response, after a brief period of rapidly repeated stimulation of the potentiation neuron. It occurs due to an accumulation of Ca2+ in the postsynaptic neuron
LTP is a type of synaptic plasticity where there is generation of new synapses associated with memory formation in hippocampus 



Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 140

questions.text: In what stage of sleep are K-complexes and sleep spindles visible?
questions.solution:
K-complexes: High voltage biphasic waves (single wave with both positive and negative components).
Sleep spindles: 1-2 s bursts of 12-14 Hz activity in the brain.

Both the above-mentioned features are of Stage 2 of NREM sleep.




Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 268-272

questions.text: Which of these mediates attention and concentration?
questions.solution:
Attention and concentration are functions of the Frontal Lobe. 
Hypothalamus mediates and controls body temperature, hunger and thirst, mood, sex drive, blood pressure and sleep
Parietal Lobe functions include sensory perception and integration which includes touch, pain, temperature, and the sense of limb.
Basal Ganglia Functions include motor control and learning, executive functions along with behaviors/emotions.


Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 270

questions.text: Which method from the list below is used to examine current flow within a single ion channel?
questions.solution:
The Patch Clamp technique can be used to study the current across a few or a single ion channel. Only a few transport proteins(possibly even one) are typically present in the membrane patch beneath the pipette tip, enabling a thorough biophysical analysis of these proteins.

questions.solution:

Golgi tendon organ is for sensing tension, it is present near the tendon & mediates the inverse stretch reflex.

afferents of both Muscle spindle and GTO is A alpha fibre.

questions.text: A 2-year-old male appears with pellagra-like lesions and urine that contains amino acids. Out of the four siblings in the family, two are experiencing the same symptoms while two siblings, and the parents remain unaffected. The most likely conclusion is:
questions.solution:
Hartnup disease is an autosomal recessive disorder resulting in impaired functioning of transport protein in intestines and kidneys. This results in wasting of neutral amino acids which manifests as pellagra like clinical symptoms.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 298.

questions.text: Which of these is not a component of collagen?
questions.solution:
Collagen is a triple helix structure. Each chain consists of about 1000 amino acids with (gly -x-y) repeats.
One third of amino acids is glycine.
x=proline,lysine,others
y=hydroxyproline,hydroxylysine
Lysine,proline and glycine help in stabilization of triple helix structure.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st edition, Page no 17.

questions.text: Pick the incorrect change with respect to cancers
questions.solution:
(1) Methylation of tumor suppressor genes, (2) Hypomethylation of oncogenes, and (3) Loss of heterozygosity  - all are commonly seen in cancer cells. 
Methylation of tumor suppressor genes leads to their underexpression and contributes to carcinogenesis
Hypomethylation of oncogenes leads to overexpression and contributes to proliferative drive in cancer cells.
Loss of heterozygosity too is commonly seen. 

Mutations in introns (4) is incorrect with respect to cancers.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 366.

questions.text: Genetic alterations that do not change the DNA's sequence are referred to as epigenetic changes. The following can all identify epigenetic change, with the exception of:

HPLC is used in the determination of plasma levels of drugs/metabolites. 
Its also used to separate, identify, and quantify each part of a mixture.
It's not used to identify epigenetic changes.

questions.text: A 10-month-old boy who has a healthy weight is experiencing vomiting after eating fruit. He has only ever received breast milk. The physician suggests fructose intolerance as the cause. Which of the following enzymes could this child be lacking in?
questions.solution:
The symptoms of hereditary fructose intolerance occur at typically six months of age(since milk has lactose made of glucose and galactose but no fructose), following ingestion of fructose or sucrose(glucose+fructose), and include vomiting and hypoglycemia. This condition occurs due to a deficiency of the Aldolase B enzyme.

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 100.

choices.text: Increased CSF lactate is associated with a good prognosis

questions.text: After a severe brain injury, all of the following changes in brain metabolism are true, with the exception of the following:
questions.solution:
Pyruvate dehydrogenase activity (specifically E-1 subunit) declines after brain parenchymal damage - this causes lactate to accumulate in the brain and CSF and increases lactate absorption from circulation.
Hence statements (1),(2),(3) are correct.
Higher the CSF Lactate - the more the damage - the poorer the prognosis. 
The prognosis is better when CSF lactate levels reduce early in the disease.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 139.

questions.text: How do we study molecular structure?
questions.solution:
1. Electron microscopy studies the ultrastructure of a range of biological and inorganic specimens like cells/microorganisms/metals/crystals etc. 
2. Ion exchange (IEX) chromatography is a technique that is commonly used in biomolecule purification. 
3. Molecular structures are determined using X-ray crystallography. Multiple oligonucleotides, viruses, and thousands of proteins have had their structures elucidated using X-ray crystallography. 
4. Agarose gel electrophoresis is a method  of separating nucleic acids/proteins.

Reference : Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 39.

questions.text: A 6-year-old Afro-American boy was seen with chronic hemolysis, abdominal pain, and an irregular RBC shape on a peripheral smear. The cause of this disease is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 1) Point Mutation

  • The clinical presentation points towards Sickle Cell Anemia.
  • It mostly affects people of African origin.
  • It's caused by a point mutation in beta-globin's 6th codon (GAG-->GTG), which results in the substitution of a glutamate residue with a valine residue.
  • In sickle cell anemia, the peripheral blood demonstrates variable numbers of irreversibly sickled cells, reticulocytosis, and target cells, which result from red cell dehydration.
  • Howell-Jolly bodies (small nuclear remnants) also are present in red cells due to asplenia (see later). The bone marrow is hyperplastic as a result of a compensatory erythroid hyperplasia.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 641.

questions.text: Pick the combination of immunohistopathological marker that is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Carcinoma: Desmin
 
  • Desmin in muscle cells forms the scaffold on which actin and myosin contract.
  • Desmin is mostly associated with muscle tumors like, rhabdomyosarcoma.
  • As there is no mention of type of carcinoma, so most appropriate answer is option 3
Cytokeratin is the tumour marker for Carcinoma

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 332.

questions.text: Pick the option that induces apoptosis in a cell.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Glucocorticoids
 
  • Glucocorticoids are also potent inducers of apoptosis in many cell types.
  • In glucocorticoid sensitive cells, apoptosis and other cellular effects are induced through activating the glucocorticoid receptor (GR).
  • Glucocorticoids (steroids) have well-documented anti inflammatory effects, and their administration may result in weakness of the scar due to inhibition of TGF-β production and diminished fibrosis.
Hence in treatment regimens of Acute Leukemias Steroids play a major role.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 108.

questions.text: 70-year-old man spent 10–15 years working in an asbestos factory. A tumour was discovered in the right lung's apical area during a routine X-ray. The mass was subjected to a biopsy. Which of the following can be viewed under an electron microscope
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Numerous long, slender microvilli
 
  • Most common lung cancer associated with above mentioned history is Mesothelioma.

Derivatives of all three germ layers are seen

questions.text: The central lung mass of a 65-year-old chronic smoker with distal bronchiectasis and recurrent pneumonia is observed and a grayish-white tumor is resected. Which histopathological finding from the list below is most likely to occur?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Small cells with scant cytoplasm, ill-defined borders and hyperchromatic nuclei with nuclear Moulding
 
  • The most common lung cancer associated with chronic smoking is small cell carcinoma of lung. So, the histopathological finding will be small cells with scant cytoplasm, ill-defined border and hyperchromatic nuclei.
  • Small cell carcinoma is comprised of relatively small cells with scant cytoplasm, ill-defined cell borders, finely granular nuclear chromatin (salt and pepper pattern), and absent or inconspicuous nucleoli.
  • The cells are round, oval, or spindle shaped, and nuclear molding is prominent. There is no absolute size for the tumor cells, but in general they are smaller than three times the diameter of a small resting lymphocyte (a size of about 25 µm).
  • The mitotic count is high. The cells grow in clusters that exhibit neither glandular nor squamous organization.
  • Necrosis is common and often extensive. Basophilic staining of vascular walls due to encrustation by DNA from necrotic tumor cells (Azzopardi effect) is frequently present.


Fig: Small cell carcinoma showing islands of small, deeply basophilic cells and areas of necrosis.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 718.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman underwent right hemithyroidectomy due to what appears to be a long-standing nodule in the right lobe measuring 2 cm by 2 cm. Histopathological evidence points to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Papillary carcinoma
 

  • Nuclear clearing causing the Orphan Annie eye appearance in the histopathology image - empty-looking nuclei - this points towards Papillary Carcinoma. 
  • Its called Orphan Annie eye due to its resemblance to the eyes of an American comic character "Orhan Annie"


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1088.

questions.text: One can find which of these in Schwannoma?

Verocay bodies (Nuclear palisading around the fibrillary process)- seen in cellular area. 



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1237.

questions.text: Which of the following does not have use for Cholinomimetic?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1): Bradycardia
 
  • Cholinomimetics cannot be used in bradycardia. 
  • They cause bradycardia by its action on M2 receptors on the heart. 
  • ACh hyperpolarizes the SA nodal cells and decreases their rate of diastolic depolarization. As a result, rate of impulse generation is reduced which leads to bradycardia or even cardiac arrest may occur
Option 2- Use in Glaucoma -Miotics increase the tone of ciliary muscle (attached to scleral spur) as well as that of sphincter pupillae which pull on and somehow improve alignment of the trabeculae so that outflow facility is increased. As a result i.o.t. falls in open angle glaucoma.

Option 3- Use in Myasthenia gravis - Cholinomimetics improve muscle contraction by allowing ACh released from prejunctional endings to accumulate and act on the receptors over a larger area, as well as by directly depolarizing the endplate.

Option 4 - Use in Post surgical atony or ileus - This may be relieved by 0.5–1 mg subcutaneous neostigmine, provided no organic obstruction is present by activating Bowel and Bladder smooth muscle.

* [Extra Edge]: Direct Agonist Vs Indirect Agonist
 



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 114.

questions.text: Pick the option that is not a tertiary amine derivative.
questions.solution:
Correct answer is (Option 2): Glycopyrrolate.

* Audio Explanation:

All the anticholinergic drugs given in the option are Tertiary amines means they have a nonpolar tertiary amino N, rendering the compound lipid soluble except Glycopyrrolate which is a Quaternary amine i.e., has a quaternary N+—rendering it lipid insoluble.
Because of these advantages Glycopyrrolate is used for preanaesthetic medication and during anaesthesia.

Examples of some Quaternary compounds:

  • Anticholinergics - Glycopyrrolate, Isopropamide
  • Anticholinesterase - Neostigmine

These drugs have certain common features:

  • Incomplete oral absorption (10–30%).
  • Poor penetration in brain and eye; central and ocular effects are not seen after parenteral/ oral administration.
  • Elimination is generally slower; majority are longer acting than atropine.
  • Have higher nicotinic blocking property. 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 124, 127.

questions.text: Which of the following has a molecular weight of 30,000, expands the plasma similarly to albumin, generates less hypersensitivity reactions, but needs to be used with care?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Polygeline

  • Polygeline is a polymer of urea and polypeptides derived from degraded gelatin.
  • The mean molecular weight of the polygeline molecules is 35000 with a range of 5000 to 50000. Polygeline is readily excreted in the urine so has a short half-life of about 3-6 hours.
  • This half-life increases in patients with impaired renal function to about 16 hours.
  • Hypersensitivity reactions are fewer compared to other plasma expanders and histamine release has been reported in few cases which may result in hypotension, bronchospasm and skin rash.


Online Reference: Singh A, Ali S, Shetty R. Effectiveness and Safety of Polygeline in Patients with Hypovolemia due to Trauma. J Emerg Trauma Shock. 2017 Jul-Sep;10(3):116-120. doi: 10.4103/JETS.JETS_120_16. PMID: 28855773; PMCID: PMC5566017.

* Audio Reference:

questions.text: Pick the option that is true for Penicillin G.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3)   Used for treatment of rat bite fever


* [Extra Edge]: Penicillin G

  • Its narrow spectrum
  • Its parenterally infused antibiotic
  • Its action is prolonged by blockage of renal secretion by probenecid.
  • It's active against Streptobacillus moniliformis and can be used to treat rare infections like Rat-bite Fever.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 768.

questions.text: Choose the statement that is untrue for NSAIDs.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Used in Neuropathic Pain.
  • NSAIDs are helpful for nociceptive pain (they inhibit COX which produces Prostaglandins which mediates nociceptive pain) but cannot relieve neuropathic pain as the physiologic process behind both are different.
  • NSAIDs do not affect the tenderness induced by direct application of PGs, but block the pain sensitizing mechanism induced by bradykinin, TNFα, interleukins (ILs) and other analgesic substances primarily by inhibiting COX-2. This constitutes the peripheral component of the analgesic action of NSAIDs. They are, therefore, more effective against inflammation associated pain. Drugs like Gabapentin/SSRIs are used for Neuropathic pain.

Option 2 and 3 are correct regarding NSAIDs interaction: Renal effects of NSAIDs become significant in those with CHF, hypovolemia, hepatic cirrhosis, renal disease and in patients receiving diuretics or antihypertensives. In them Na+ retention and edema can occur; diuretic and antihypertensive drug effects are blunted.
Option 4 is correct as NSAIDs have been marketed in topical formulations (mostly as gels) for application over painful muscles or joints.
It is presumed that the drug would penetrate to the subjacent tissues attaining high concentrations in the affected muscles/joints, while maintaining low blood levels. Some Topical Preparations are Diclofenac gel 1%, Ibuprofen 10% etc.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 210.

questions.text: Haloperidol (5 mg) was initiated as a treatment for schizophrenia in a young male patient. He arrived at the hospital with his father on the third day, his eyes rolling upward. There were no signs of spasticity or other abnormalities after a thorough neurological evaluation. It was discovered that visual acuity was normal. The most likely conclusion is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Acute dystonia

The clinical scenario in question describes Oculogyric crisis.

* Oculogyric Crisis
Oculogyric crisis (OGC) is the name of a dystonic reaction to certain drugs (mostly antidopaminergic drugs like Haloperidol) characterized by a prolonged involuntary upward deviation of the eyes. It's a type of acute dystonia.



* Audio Explanation:


Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 366.

choices.text: Used in ovarian, cervix and breast cancer

questions.text: Which of these is not true about paclitaxel?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) 
 
  • Paclitaxel stabilizes microtubule and prevent polymerization.
  • It binds to β-tubulin and enhances its polymerization to form excess of microtubules: a mechanism opposite to that of vinca alkaloids.
  • The microtubules are stabilized and their depolymerization is prevented. This stability disrupts the normal dynamic reorganization of the microtubule network that is essential for interphase and mitotic functions.
  • Abnormal arrays or ‘bundles’ of microtubules are produced throughout the cell cycle.
  • It is a complex diterpin taxane obtained from bark of the Western yew tree not E.coli.
  • The approved indications of paclitaxel are metastatic ovarian and breast carcinoma after failure of first line chemotherapy and relapse cases. It has also shown efficacy in advanced cases of head and neck cancer, small cell lung cancer, esophageal adenocarcinoma, urinary and hormone refractory prostate cancer. AIDS related Kaposi’s sarcoma also responds.
  • The major toxicity is reversible myelosuppression (mainly granulocytopenia) and ‘stocking and glove’ neuropathy. Nausea, chest pain, arthralgia, myalgia, mucositis and edema can be troublesome.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 925.

choices.text: Osteoporosis leading to hip fracture in women

questions.text: Pick the option that is not a side effect of long-term use of PPI.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Hypothyroidism

Proton Pump Inhibitors have not yet been found to cause hypothyroidism.

They inhibit acid secretion - their long-term use increases the chances of infections like Community-acquired pneumonia
and Clostridium difficile. They can also lead to hypocalcemia leading to osteoporosis.

questions.text: What is Abatacept, a new drug inhibiting costimulation, used for treating?

questions.text: Which medication is recommended for pseudomembranous enterocolitis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Oral vancomycin
 
  • Drug of choice is fidaxomicin. But among the given option the best option is oral vancomycin used in fulminant cases.
  • Clostridium difficile: pseudomembranous enterocolitis; mostly associated with the use of clindamycin, tetracyclines, aminoglycosides, ampicillin, etc. It is more common after colorectal surgery. The organism produces an enterotoxin which damages gut mucosa forming plaques; metronidazole and vancomycin are the drugs of choice

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 806.

choices.text: Chimeric monoclonal antibody against CD-20 B cell antigen
Most common side effect is infusion reaction
First FDA drug approved for resistant lymphomas

questions.text: Which of these is not true for rituximab?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Dose independent pharmacokinetics:

Malignant cells express certain antigens against whom antibodies can be developed. CD20 is such antigen.

Option 1 : Rituximab is one such Monoclonal antibody that binds to CD20 B-cell antigen expressed on the surface of lymphocytes, plasma cells and B-cell lymphomas.

Option 2 : Infusion reactions consisting of chills, rigor, fever, urticarial rashes are the most common adverse effects. Pretreatment with corticosteroids and antihistaminics is done to prevent infusion reactions.

Option 3 : Rituximab was the first MAb used for the treatment of lymphomas. Follicular lymphoma was the first cancer to be treated.

Option 4 : It follows Non-linear PK at low doses and Linear PK at high doses after saturation of target

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 932.

questions.text: Which of the following cephalosporins has been shown to be effective against MRSA (Methicillin Resistant Staphylococcus Aureus)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Ceftobiprole

5th generation cephalosporin like Ceftobiprole are useful against MRSA
Generation Drugs Coverage Mnemonic
1st Generation Cefazolin, Cephalexin Gram-positive cocci, PEcK (Proteus, E. coli, Klebsiella) "1st: PEcK"
2nd Generation Cefaclor, Cefuroxime, Cefoxitin HENPEcK (Haemophilus, Enterobacter, Neisseria, Proteus, E. coli, Klebsiella) "2nd: HEN"
3rd Generation Ceftriaxone, Cefotaxime, Ceftazidime (contains "Z") Broad Gram-negative, Pseudomonas ( Ceftazidime covers Pseudomonas) "3rd: Pseudomonas (3rd gen containing Z in name covers pseudomonas)
4th Generation Cefepime, Cefepirome Broad coverage: Gram-positive, Pseudomonas "4th: Pseudomonas+" name contains -pi- 
5th Generation Ceftaroline, Ceftabiprole MRSA, Gram-negative (similar to 3rd gen) "5th: MRSA" Name contains - rol

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 780.

questions.text: Pick the Antibiotic that is characterized by time-dependent killing and post-antibiotic effect(PAE)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Clindamycin

β-lactams, glycopeptides and macrolides produce ‘time dependent killing’, i.e. antimicrobial action depends on the length of time the concentration remains above the MIC; division of daily dose improves the effect.

Drugs having TDK with post antibiotic effect: -
  • Clindamycin
  • Clarithromycin
  • Linezolid
  • Tetracyclines
  • Azoles
Killing Type Key Drugs Mechanism
Time-Dependent Killing - Beta-lactams (e.g., Penicillins, Cephalosporins 1st and 2nd gen), Vancomycin- Clindamycin - Effectiveness depends on time above MIC.
Concentration-Dependent Killing - Aminoglycosides- Daptomycin- 3rd & 4th Gen Cephalosporins , Azithromycin, Doxycycline - Effectiveness increases with higher drug concentration.
Both - Fluoroquinolones- Clarithromycin - Needs both time above MIC and high concentration for maximum effect.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 748.

questions.text: What does Major Histocompatibility Complex (MHC)-1 and -2 do?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Present antigens for recognition by T-cell antigen receptors

The main function of the MHC molecule is to bind peptide fragments of foreign protein for presentation to appropriate antigen-specific T cells.
  • Class I MHC molecules display peptides that are derived from cytoplasmic proteins, including normal proteins and virus- and tumor-specific antigens, which are all recognized bound to class I MHC molecules by CD8+ T cells.
  • Class II MHC molecules present antigens derived from extracellular microbes and proteins following their internalization into endosomes or lysosomes.
  • MHC molecules play several key roles in regulating T cell–mediated immune responses.
  1. First, because different antigenic peptides bind to different MHC molecules, it follows that an individual mounts an immune response against a protein antigen only if he or she inherits an MHC variant that can bind peptides derived from the antigen and present it to T cells.
  2. Second, by segregating cytoplasmic and internalized antigens, MHC molecules ensure that the correct immune response is mounted against different microbes—CTL-mediated killing of cells harboring cytoplasmic microbes and tumor antigens, and helper T cell–mediated antibody production and macrophage activation to combat extracellular and phagocytosed microbes.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 195.

questions.text: Which indicator is used in RNTCP to measure the impact of the control measures?
questions.solution:
Incidence of new cases is the key indicator in program like RNTCP.
 

Importance of Incidence as an Indicator

  1. Monitoring Program Effectiveness:

    • A decrease in the incidence of new cases suggests that the control measures are effectively reducing transmission within the community.

  2. Assessing Impact of Interventions:

    • Tracking incidence helps evaluate the impact of specific interventions, such as improved diagnostic methods, treatment adherence initiatives, and public awareness campaigns.

  3. Resource Allocation:

    • Understanding incidence rates helps health authorities allocate resources more effectively, targeting areas with higher rates of infection.

  4. Public Health Planning:

    • Incidence data inform public health strategies and policy decisions, guiding interventions and funding priorities.

  5. Global and National Comparisons:

    • Incidence rates allow for comparisons across regions and countries, helping to identify successful strategies and areas needing improvement.

Measuring Incidence

  • New Cases: The incidence typically refers to the number of newly diagnosed cases within a specific time period, usually reported annually.
  • Surveillance Systems: Effective surveillance systems are essential for accurately capturing new cases, ensuring timely reporting and follow-up.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 210.

questions.text: At what point is a pandemic of H1N1 suspected?
questions.solution:
An epidemic occurring over a very wide area, crossing international boundaries, and usually affecting a large number of people refers to pandemic.
Only some pandemics cause severe disease in some individuals or at a population level.
Characteristics of an infectious agent influencing the causation of a pandemic include : the agent must be able to infect humans, to cause disease in humans and to spread easily from human to human .
Examples are influenza pandemics and cholera pandemics.

Among the given options, the best option is option 2.

questions.text: To determine the connection between smoking and lung cancer, a study was conducted. The connection was found to be stronger in those who exercised less and weaker in those who exercised more. Exercise, in this case, happens to be a:
questions.solution:
Definitions of terms in options.
  • Bias : An intentional/unintentional but systematic mistake/error in the design, recruiting, data collecting, or analysis that causes a false estimate of the true impact of exposure on the outcome.
  • Confounder: The distortion of the association between health outcome and exposure by an external, third variable called a confounder.
  • Effect Modifier: Effect modifier is a variable that differentially (positively and negatively) modifies the observed effect of a risk factor on disease status.
Its distinct from confounding; it occurs when the magnitude of the effect of the primary exposure on an outcome (i.e., the association) differs depending on the level of a third variable.

In the above question- its clear - the primary exposure is smoking and outcome is lung cancer and exercise is effect modifier causing difference in magnitude of observed effect. (incidence of lung cancer)
Hence, option (3) is the correct answer.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 80, 81.

    SD = ( x-x )2É³-1        [ Sample size < 30]

questions.text: The Chandler Index is a crucial epidemiological tool. What is the least likely application for it?

questions.text: Which of the following is not true for obstructive sleep apnea syndrome.
questions.solution:
Obstructive sleep apnea-hypopnea syndrome(OSAHS) occurs in around 1-4% of middle-aged males and is about half as common in women i.e Males are more commonly affected as compared to females.
Other options are correct.
 
  • Definition: OSA is defined on the basis of nocturnal and daytime symptoms as well as sleep study findings. Diagnosis requires the patient to have:
  1. either symptoms of nocturnal breathing disturbances (snoring, snorting, gasping, or breathing pauses during sleep) or daytime sleepiness or fatigue that occurs despite sufficient opportunity to sleep and is unexplained by other medical problems; and
  2. five or more episodes of obstructive apnea or hypopnea per hour of sleep (the apnea-hypopnea index [AHI], calculated as the number of episodes divided by the number of hours of sleep) documented during a sleep study.
  • OSA also may be diagnosed in the absence of symptoms if the AHI is ≥15 episodes/h. Each episode of apnea or hypopnea represents a reduction in breathing for at least 10 s and commonly results in a ≥3% drop in oxygen saturation or a brain cortical arousal.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2205, 2206.

questions.text: Pick the option that is not an absolute contraindication for corneal transplantation
questions.solution:
TB meningitis is NOT an absolute contraindication for corneal transplantation

Tissue from patients exhibiting risk factors for, clinical evidence of, or physical evidence of relevant communicable disease and high-risk behavior associated with relevant communicable disease may not be suitable for transplant.

The possible contraindications include:
  • Rabies,
  • Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C,
  • Creutzfeldt-Jacob Disease,
  • Retinoblastoma,
  • Bacterial/ fungal keratitis,
  • Bacterial/ fungal endophthalmitis,
  • HIV, Herpes Simplex Virus,
  • Prion Disease,
  • Human T-Cell Lymphotrophic Virus (HTLV),
  • Ocular Adenocarcinoma,
  • Malignant Tumors of Anterior Segment,
  • Reye Syndrome,
  • Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE)
  • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy,
  • Leukemias, Active disseminated lymphomas,
  • Active infectious endocarditis,
  • active septicemia, Dementia,
  • Down Syndrome,
  • Congenital Rubella,
  • Recipient of non-synthetic dura mater graft,
  • Neurological Diseases of unknown cause.

Reference: Parsons' Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 197.

  • Other genes such as PITX3 and PAX6 can also contribute to congenital cataracts, but CRYAA is particularly significant.

questions.text: When there has been a hypoxic damage, the cornea swells up from the accumulation of
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Lactate
 
  • When there is hypoxic damage, the cornea can swell up, resulting in corneal edema.
  • Hypoxia refers to a lack of oxygen supply to the tissues.
  • In cases of hypoxia, anaerobic metabolism occurs in the cornea.
  • Anaerobic metabolism leads to the accumulation of lactate, a byproduct of glucose metabolism in the absence of oxygen.
  • The accumulation of lactate in the cornea disrupts osmotic balance, causing edema or swelling.
  • Corneal edema can impair vision and cause discomfort.


Reference: Parsons' Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 232.

questions.text: After using eyeglasses, a patient complains of impaired vision, which gradually gets worse in both meridians. Which of the following statements regarding this ailment is not true ?

Cylindrical lenses (Option 4) are typically used to correct astigmatism, not to increase distortion.

Other options:
  • The condition described in the clinical scenario is consistent with the phenomenon known as "pincushion distortion (Option 1).
  • "Pincushion distortion is commonly observed when using convex lenses, which is thicker at the center and thinner at the edges. (Option 2).
  • It causes a gradual worsening of vision in both meridians.
  • Aniseikonia (Option 3): Condition where there is a difference in the perceived size or shape of objects between the two eyes. Pincushion distortion can cause aniseikonia and result in impaired vision.

questions.text: A foreign body made of iron has been retained. Which research is most effective for keeping an eye on vision?

  • ERG (Electroretinogram): This test measures the electrical responses of various cell types in the retina to light stimulation. It can assess the function of the retina and is particularly useful in cases where there may be damage or concerns about the function of the retina due to a foreign body or other trauma.
  • Additionally, full-field ERG testing has a role in ocular trauma in establishing a diagnosis of siderosis when an iron-containing small metallic intraocular foreign body is suspected, and serial ERGs can be helpful in monitoring the health of the retina in these cases.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 463.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions warrants laser trabeculoplasty?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Pseudoexfoliative glaucoma
 
  • Laser trabeculoplasty is a treatment option used to manage certain types of glaucoma, which is characterized by increased intraocular pressure (IOP).
  • Pseudoexfoliative glaucoma is a specific type of glaucoma associated with the buildup of extracellular material on ocular structures, particularly the trabecular meshwork.
  • Pseudoexfoliation syndrome is an age-related degenerative disorder, more commonly seen in elderly women. The pathogenesis involves the deposition of a grey-white fibrillary substance derived from abnormal extracellular matrix metabolism in ocular and other tissues.
  • Argon or selective laser trabeculoplasty can be performed in XFS if the angle is open enough to allow laser application
  • Laser trabeculoplasty can be effective in improving the outflow of fluid through the trabecular meshwork and reducing the IOP in pseudoexfoliative glaucoma.
Indications: 
1.Patients with OAG, uncontrolled by medical therapy - the IOP remains above the target IOP despite maximum medical therapy that can be tolerated.
2.In patients with OAG with poor compliance to medical treatment, the IOP remains above the target IOP, and the glaucomatous optic atrophy worsens.
3.Patients with OAG with poor tolerance to medical therapy.
4.Patients with pseudoexfoliation or pigmentary glaucomas.
5. Angle-closure glaucoma with a patent iridotomy.
6.When the glaucoma surgery needs to be deferred or delayed

Contraindications: 
1.Inflammatory glaucoma - as post-laser inflammations will increase, leading to further IOP spikes.
2.Advanced glaucoma
3.Poor visualization of the TM due to synechiae- as the site of action is trabecular meshwork.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1076.

questions.text: Which of the following diagnostic techniques is not performed on a patient with dilated pupils?

choices.text: Number of cataract surgeries leading to sight restoration

questions.text: Choose the option that is an output indicator for NPCB.
questions.solution:
An output indicator measures the direct results of activities or services provided, such as the number of services delivered or the number of actions completed.
  • Number of cataract surgeries leading to sight restoration: This is an output indicator because it directly measures the result of a specific service provided (cataract surgery) and its immediate impact (sight restoration).
  • Decrease in prevalence of blindness: This is an outcome indicator because it measures the broader, long-term effect of interventions on public health.
  • Number of school children provided glasses for refraction correction: While important, this is also an output indicator but specific to another service. However, it's not the most direct output linked to the primary goal of NPCB, which focuses on reducing blindness, with cataract surgery being a major intervention.
  • Number of eye surgeons trained: This is an input indicator, as it measures the resources or activities invested in the program, not the direct result of services provided.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 458, 503.

questions.text: What is the normal value of Arden index?
questions.solution:
The Arden ratio, the ratio of the Light peak (Lp) to dark trough (Dt) is used to determine the normalcy of the results.

An Arden ratio of 1.80 or greater is normal, 1.65 to 1.80 is subnormal, and < 1.65 is significantly subnormal.

The EOG is abnormal in:
1.Best vitelliform macular dystrophy (early stage)
2. macular dystrophy (advanced stage)
3.Pattern dystrophies (normal or modestly subnormal)
4.Retinitis pigmentosa and rod-cone dystrophies
5.Oguchi disease
6.Fundus Albipunctatus (no notable light rise with dark adaptation of 15 minutes)
7.Choroideremia
8.Gyrate atrophy
9.Diffuse choroidal atrophy
10.Hypertensive retinopathy
11.Retinal detachment
12.Silicone oil exposure during retinal detachment repair surgery, even 4 mo after removal
13.Chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine toxicity
14.Desferrioxamine
15.Diabetes, worsening with the duration of diabetes
16.Retained intraocular iron particles (siderosis bulbi)

18.Choroidal malignant melanoma

The EOG is normal in:
Dominantly inherited drusen of Bruch's membrane
Congenital achromatopsia
Progressive diffuse cone dystrophy
Autosomal recessive and X-linked recessive congenital stationary nyctalopia
Carotid occlusive disease
Optic nerve disease

questions.text: A 45-year-old male is found to have chronic, productive cough associated with clubbing. Crackles and wheeze were heard during auscultation. Which investigation will be most helpful in confirming the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. HRCT
 
  • The above clinical scenario is suggestive of Bronchiectasis.
  • HRCT (High-Resolution Computed Tomography): HRCT is the gold standard for diagnosing bronchiectasis, which is a likely cause of chronic productive cough and clubbing

DIAGNOSIS: 
  • The diagnosis usually is based on presentation with a persistent chronic cough and sputum production accompanied by consistent radiographic features. Although chest radiographs lack sensitivity, the presence of “tram tracks” indicating dilated airways is consistent with bronchiectasis.
  • Chest CT is more specific for bronchiectasis and is the imaging modality of choice for confirming the diagnosis.
  • CT findings include airway dilation (detected as parallel “tram tracks” or as the “signet-ring sign”—a cross-sectional area of the airway with a diameter at least 1.5 times that of the adjacent vessel), lack of bronchial tapering (including the presence of tubular structures within 1 cm from the pleural surface), bronchial wall thickening in dilated airways, inspissated secretions (e.g., the “tree-in-bud” pattern), or cysts emanating from the bronchial wall (especially pronounced in cystic bronchiectasis).



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2174.

questions.text: A young girl who complained of spontaneous movements was identified as having Sydenham chorea, which is symptomatic of acute rheumatic fever. Carditis or arthritic complaints are not present. A bad throat culture exists. Which of the following is the strongest indication of a recent streptococcal infection
questions.solution:
Antistreptolysin O (ASLO) titre is a blood test to measure antibodies against streptolysin O, a substance produced by group A streptococcus bacteria. The sensitivity of this test is around 95% which indicates that a negative result means no streptococcal infection.

questions.text: Penicillin was being used to treat a patient. He started to look paler, but there was no wheezing, urticaria, or shortness of breath. Investigation revealed that his blood had anti-penicillin antibodies. What kind of hypersensitive reaction did this patient most likely experience?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Type II hypersensitivity
 
  • This is an example of a type II, antibody-mediated hypersensitivity reaction. The paleness points towards Antibody-mediated RBC destruction causing anemia and pallor.
  • Type I hypersensitivity is IgE mediated with the release of mast granules causing wheezing/urticaria/SOB.  
  • Type III Hypersensitivity involves immune complex formation, type IV is cell-mediated in nature (macrophages/T-h1 cells) being the mediators (no antibody formation).




Reference: Jawetz, Melnick & Adelberg's Medical Microbiology, 27th edition, Page no 145.

questions.text: Pick the option that is not an indicator of chronic congestive heart failure.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Sirtuins
 
  • CHF is a condition characterized by the heart's inability to pump blood efficiently, leading to fluid accumulation and various physiological changes. Several biomarkers and clinical indicators are used to evaluate and diagnose CHF.
  • Sirtuins are a class of enzymes involved in cellular metabolism and aging, are not specifically associated with CHF.

On the other hand, the other options are commonly used as indicators of CHF:
  1. CRP (C-reactive protein): Elevated levels of CRP can indicate inflammation, which is often present in CHF.
  2. Brain natriuretic peptide (BNP): BNP is a hormone released by the heart in response to increased stretching of the cardiac chambers, which is a characteristic of CHF.
  3. Troponin: Elevated levels of troponin, particularly troponin T or I, are associated with myocardial damage and can be seen in CHF, especially in acute exacerbations or coexisting myocardial infarction.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1932, 1937, 1939.

questions.text: What does high calcium intake lead to?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Milk-Alkali syndrome

High calcium intake can lead to the development of Milk-Alkali Syndrome. This condition occurs due to excessive consumption of calcium-containing products, such as milk or calcium supplements, combined with excessive intake of absorbable alkali (such as antacids containing calcium carbonate). The syndrome is characterized by the triad of hypercalcemia (high levels of calcium in the blood), metabolic alkalosis (high pH of the blood), and kidney dysfunction.

The other options listed are not directly associated with high calcium intake.






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3173.

choices.text: Put a handkerchief in his mouth and restrain him by holding hands and legs
Take him away from the train, give him medicine with small sips of water and wait for seizure to resolve

questions.text: While waiting for the train, a passenger started having seizures at the train station. It was discovered that he wears a wristband identifying him as an epilepsy patient who has a medication in his pocket. What are your next actions?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Take him away from the train, make him lie down and call for the hospital

Take him away from the train, make him lie down, and call for medical assistance or the hospital.
If someone is having a seizure, the following steps can be taken:
  1. Ensure the person's safety: Move the individual away from any potential dangers or hazards, such as sharp objects or traffic.
  2. Support their head and protect them: Cushion their head with something soft to prevent injury during the seizure. It is important not to restrain the person or put anything in their mouth.
  3. Clear the area: Create space around the person by moving objects and people away. This helps prevent accidental contact during the seizure.
  4. Time the seizure: Note the start time of the seizure. If the seizure lasts longer than five minutes or if the person has difficulty breathing, it is crucial to call for emergency medical assistance immediately.
  5. After the seizure: Once the seizure ends, check the person's responsiveness and breathing. If they are not responsive or are having difficulty breathing, perform CPR if you are trained to do so or wait for medical professionals to arrive.
  6. Nothing should be administered in the mouth during active seizure episode as it may lead to aspiration of contents.



Reference: First Aid for Seizures, CDC guidelines (2024), URL: https://www.cdc.gov/epilepsy/first-aid-for-seizures/index.html

questions.text: A 15 year old boy presented with headache vomiting and altered sensorium. On probing his parents gave a history of recent URTI after swimming at a near by pond.  He was diagnosed to have meningitis and he succumbed to his illness on day five.  What is the most likely etiological agent among the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Naegleria fowleri
 
  • Naegleria fowleri is a free-living amoeba that can cause a rare but severe infection of the central nervous system called primary amebic meningoencephalitis (PAM).
  • It is commonly associated with warm freshwater environments such as lakes and hot springs. Infections occur when contaminated water enters the nasal passages and allows the amoeba to reach the brain.
  • The symptoms of Naegleria fowleri infection typically include a severe headache, high fever, neck stiffness, and often purulent nasal discharge.
  • The infection progresses rapidly and can lead to coma and death within a few days.






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1718, 1719.

questions.text: A woman in her 70s had an influenza illness but resisted getting the vaccine. After contracting pneumonia, she passed away within 5 days. What  of the following organisms cause post-influenza pneumonia most frequently?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1:  Staphylococcus aureus
 
  • Following an influenza illness, secondary bacterial pneumonia is a common complication, and Staphylococcus aureus is one of the predominant bacteria associated with this condition. Influenza infection weakens the respiratory tract, making it more susceptible to bacterial invasion. Staphylococcus aureus is a bacterium that can cause severe pneumonia, particularly in individuals with underlying health conditions or weakened immune systems.
  • Legionella pneumophila, a bacterium responsible for Legionnaires' disease, can also cause pneumonia. However, it is not typically associated with post-influenza pneumonia.
  • Measles and cytomegalovirus (CMV) are viral infections that can lead to pneumonia but are not commonly seen as direct complications following influenza.






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1011, 1519.

questions.text: Which of these heart sounds are not heard in chronic mitral stenosis?
questions.solution:
Third heart sound is NOT heard in Chronic MS
 
  • Option 1: The OS is followed by a low-pitched, rumbling, diastolic murmur, heard best at the apex with the patient in the left lateral recumbent position
  • Option 3: The opening snap (OS) of the mitral valve is most readily audible in expiration at, or just medial to, the cardiac apex. The time interval between A2 and OS varies inversely with the severity of the MS.
  • Option 4: The first heart sound (S1) is usually accentuated in the early stages of the disease and slightly delayed.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1820, 1992.

questions.text: A patient exhibits angina, syncope, and dyspnea. Which explanation is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Aortic stenosis
 
  • Aortic stenosis is a condition characterized by the narrowing of the aortic valve, which obstructs the flow of blood from the left ventricle into the aorta. This obstruction leads to increased workload on the left ventricle and can result in symptoms such as angina (chest pain or discomfort), syncope (fainting), and dyspnea (shortness of breath).
  • The angina occurs due to inadequate blood supply and oxygen to the myocardium (heart muscle) as the narrowed aortic valve restricts blood flow. Syncope can occur as a result of reduced cardiac output and inadequate perfusion to the brain. Dyspnea is often experienced due to the increased pressure and fluid backup in the lungs caused by the stenotic aortic valve.
  • Aortic regurgitation (option 2) is the backflow of blood from the aorta into the left ventricle due to an incompetent aortic valve. While it can cause symptoms such as dyspnea, it is less commonly associated with angina and syncope.
  • Atrial septal defect (option 3) and ventricular septal defect (option 4) are congenital heart defects characterized by abnormal communications between the atria or ventricles, respectively. While they can cause symptoms such as dyspnea, they are less likely to manifest with angina and syncope.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1981.

questions.text: Pick the one that is usually not seen in rheumatic heart disease.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: PS
 
  • Rheumatic heart disease primarily affects the mitral and aortic valves.
  • The mitral valve is most commonly involved, leading to mitral stenosis (MS) or mitral regurgitation.
  • The aortic valve can also be affected, causing aortic stenosis (AS) or aortic regurgitation.
  • Pulmonary stenosis (PS), is generally not associated with rheumatic heart disease. PS is more commonly a congenital heart defect, meaning it is present from birth, rather than a consequence of rheumatic fever. It is a common finding in Noonan syndrome.

Valve abnormalities commonly seen in rheumatic heart disease (RHD):





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2004.

questions.text: Select the most effective treatment of severe malaria.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Artesunate

Artesunate (Artemisinin based combination therapy) is the best treatment for severe/complicated cases of Malaria.

Option 1: Doxycycline is the DOC in malaria prophylaxis if the duration of travel is <6 weeks and in treatment if ACT is not available.

Option 2: Primaquine kills hypnozoites and thus provides radical cure by preventing relapse.

Option 3: Chloroquine is used for treatment of uncomplicated malaria caused by P. Vivax, uncomplicated malaria in pregnancy and in case of ACT resistance

questions.text: Choose the pulmonary symptom that is NOT correctly matched with the corresponding non-pulmonary association:
questions.solution:
1. Cyanosis-Anxiety is the wrong match
 
  • Cyanosis is seen in hypoxemic respiratory disorders that result in >5 g of deoxygenated hemoglobin/dL. It is NOT seen in Anxiety or Panic attacks.
 
  • Option 2: Wheezing and rhonchi can occur in CHF with congestion of the bronchial mucosa and sometimes lead to a misdiagnosis (and inappropriate treatment) of asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
 
  • Option 3: Tachypnea occurs in metabolic acidosis as a compensatory mechanism to promote CO2 washout.
 
  • Option 4: Chest pain is the most common symptom of Acute pericarditis. The pain of acute pericarditis is often severe, retrosternal and/or left precordial, and referred to the neck, arms, or left shoulder.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1937, 2019, 2132, 3115.

questions.text: Which of the following treatments is used in a patient with Anti-Phospholipid Antibody syndrome to stop additional abortions?
questions.solution:
• In a patient with Antiphospholipid Antibody Syndrome, Pregnancy related morbidity and additional abortions are prevented by a combination of heparin with aspirin 80 mg daily.
  • This helps in preventing/developing thrombotic events leading to abortions.
  • Aspirin + LMWH is the cornerstone of APLA management during pregnancy.
  • Close monitoring of the pregnancy and careful management of anticoagulation are key to minimizing risks for both mother and fetus.
  • Anticoagulation is continued postpartum to reduce the risk of venous thromboembolism, particularly in the first 6 weeks.
  • LMWH or warfarin can be used postpartum.
  • Heparin is typically discontinued 24 hours before labor induction or scheduled C-section to reduce the risk of bleeding.
  • Delivery is usually planned around 37-39 weeks, depending on maternal and fetal conditions.
  • Steroids (prednisolone) or IVIg may be considered in specific cases, especially if there is an associated autoimmune disease, but these are not routinely recommended solely for APLA.


Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no:1116.
