questions.text: A man who has a history of exposure to pigeon excrement is experiencing bilateral crepitations in the base of the lungs as well as symptoms of pneumonitis. Which statement about this condition is accurate?
questions.solution:
The given case fits the description of Hypersensitivity Pneumonitis. 
Amongst the given options - option (2) is best answer. 

Hypersensitivity Pneumonitis 
 
It is a chronic lung inflammatory illness that affects the alveolar walls and terminal airways in a susceptible host and is brought on by repeated inhalation of a range of organic substances.

Common types and causative agents are: 
1. Farmer's lungs.  --   Moldy hay --- Thermophilic actinomycetes(Putative antigen)
2. Bird Fancier's lungs -- Various birds --- Protein in avian feces (Putative antigen)
3. Cheese Workers' lungs -- Moldy cheese --- Penicillium

Surprisingly, cigarette smoking has been known to decrease its incidence. 

Pathogenesis:
Its both an immune complex­ mediated reaction (Type III) and cell-mediated hypersensitivity (Type IV) reaction.

Clinical Presentation:
It can manifest as acute, subacute, or chronic disease.
  • Acute:  Symptoms including coughing, fever, chills, and dyspnea may appear 6 to 8 hours after antigen exposure. If there is no further exposure to the antigen, the symptoms often go away in a few days.
  • Subacute: The subacute type frequently develops slowly over a few weeks and is characterized by coughing and dyspnea. If left untreated, it can proceed to cyanosis and severe dyspnea, which necessitates hospitalization.
  • Chronic: In its later stages, the chronic type of HP may be clinically indistinguishable from pulmonary fibrosis. Cough, weight loss, lethargy, and a progressive increase in dyspnea are among the symptoms. Physical examination may demonstrate digital clubbing and inspiratory crackles.

Diagnosis:
  • A combination of CT findings, history of exposure, BAL lymphocytosis and histopathology is used to know the likelihood of HSP (Hence, option 1 is incorrect - diagnosis is not based only on clinical history) 
  • CT in particular HRCT Chest is considered the investigation of choice. (option 2)

CT findings:
  • Acute HP appears with diffuse "ground-glass" infiltrates a reticulonodular pattern, or confluent alveolar opacification.
  • In subacute disease, centrilobular nodules and "ground-glass" changes predominate.
  • In chronic HP, changes include emphysema and interstitial fibrosis; honeycombing and subpleural linear opacities are common.


X ray findings:
They are not characteristic and can occur in other diseases as well. (hence, option 3 is incorrect).
They include-
1. B/L lungs have numerous tiny, poorly defined opacities (5 mm), sometimes sparing the apices and bases.
2. Ground-glass opacities, which can be patchy or diffuse.
3. Pattern of fine reticulation.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2160, 2161.

questions.text: Between peritoneum and which of the following is the Le-Veen shunt in ascites done?
questions.solution:
The LeVeen shunt a.k.a Peritoneovenous shunt designed for ascites management due to CLD.

One end of the tube is inserted into the peritoneal cavity while the other end is subcutaneously tunneled to the neck, where its inserted into the IJV and fed into the SVC.




Reference: LeVeen, H H. “The LeVeen shunt.” Annual review of medicine vol. 36 (1985): 453-69. doi:10.1146/annurev.me.36.020185.002321. URL: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/3888061/

questions.text: Select the drug that is useful for treatment of advanced prostate cancer.
questions.solution:
Goserelin
A synthetic analog of a  gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH).
Given in non-pulsatile manner(non-physiological) - it decreases testosterone production and is hence used for treating Prostate cancer.

Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 598.

choices.text: Dyscohesive ductal epithelial cells without cellular fragments
Tightly arranged ductal epithelial cells with dyscohesive bare nuclei
Polymorphism with single or arranged ductal epithelial cells

questions.text: A 17-year-old woman who had a firm, non-tender breast lump underwent Fine Needle Aspiration Cytology (FNAC). Which of the following traits would lead one to believe a benign breast tumour has been discovered?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Tightly arranged ductal epithelial cells with dyscohesive bare nuclei
 
  • In FNAC, the traits suggesting a benign breast tumor include tightly arranged ductal epithelial cells with dyscohesive bare nuclei (Option B).
  • In benign breast tumors, the cells tend to maintain their architectural organization, resulting in tightly arranged ductal epithelial cells.
  • These cells are usually uniform and show minimal variation in size, shape, and nuclear features.
  • The nuclei of these cells may appear dyscohesive or not tightly adhered to each other, meaning there is a lack of cohesive cellular clustering.



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 918.

questions.text: A couple is struggling with infertility. Following an examination, a semen study revealed that the husband had azoospermia. According to the rectal examination, the vas was not palpable. Low volume, high viscosity, and fructose were all characteristics of the semen. What might you do from there?
questions.solution:
CFTR gene mutation analysis

This is a case of obstructive azoospermia due to CBAVD

Congenital absence of the vas deferens (CAVD) is a condition in which the vasa deferentia reproductive organs fail to form properly prior to birth. It may either be unilateral (CUAVD) or bilateral (CBAVD).There are two main populations of CAVD; the larger group is associated with cystic fibrosis and occurs because of a mutation in the CFTR gene while the smaller group is associated with unilateral renal agenesis (URA). 


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 206, 207.

questions.text: An infant of six months woke up in the middle of the night sobbing from stomach ache that was eased by passing red faeces. Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Intussusception
 
  • The most likely diagnosis for an infant waking up with stomach ache and passing red feces is intussusception (Option B).
  • Intussusception occurs when one portion of the intestine telescopes into another, leading to obstruction and compromised blood supply.
  • The classic presentation includes sudden onset of severe abdominal pain, inconsolable crying, and passing of "currant jelly" stools, which are reddish due to blood mixed with mucus.
  • Prompt diagnosis and treatment are essential to prevent complications such as bowel necrosis.

* [Extra Edge]: Intussusception



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 260.

questions.text: How is a tension pneumothorax immediately managed?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Insert needle in 2nd intercostal space
 
  • In the case of a tension pneumothorax, the immediate management involves the insertion of a needle or catheter into the affected side of the chest to relieve the pressure buildup.
  • This procedure, known as needle decompression or needle thoracostomy, is typically performed in the 2nd intercostal space along the midclavicular line. It is done to rapidly release the trapped air and relieve the tension within the pleural space.
  • Once the initial needle decompression is performed, it is typically followed by the placement of a chest tube (tube thoracostomy) in the 5th intercostal space to allow for continued drainage and re-expansion of the lung.



NOTE- Previously, needle insertion was done @2nd ICS but nowadays, maximum literature recommend Needle thoracostomy @ 5th ICS in mid-axillary line through triangle of safety. 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2200.
Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 374.

questions.text: A woman in her twenties is experiencing vomiting, nausea, and stomach pain. She exhibited baldness and an epigastric crepitus, following an examination. What has been found?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Trichobezoar

* Audio Explanation:


Fig: Trichobezoar of the stomach in a girl aged 15 years

  • Trichobezoar (hair balls) are unusual and are virtually exclusively found in young psychiatric patients.
  • It is caused by the ingestion of hair, which remains undigested in the stomach. The hair ball can lead to ulceration and gastrointestinal bleeding, perforation or obstruction.
  • The diagnosis is made easily at endoscopy. A preoperative diagnosis is difficult even with high-resolution computed tomography (CT) scanning.
  • Treatment consists of removal of the bezoar, which may require open surgical treatment. Phytobezoars are made of vegetable matter and are found principally in patients who have gastric stasis, usually following gastric surgery.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1180.

choices.text: Dilated mucosal and submucosal veins in the colon

questions.text: A 65 year old man presented with history of syncope. He also complains of feeling lightheadedness and excessive bleeding and pain during defecation. Stool occult blood test for routine screening of colon cancer came back negative. There is no recent weight loss history. What is the most likely colonoscopic finding in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Dilated mucosal and submucosal veins in the colon
 
  • The most likely colonoscopic finding in this patient is dilated mucosal and submucosal veins in the colon, known as colonic angiodysplasia.
  • This condition is commonly seen in older individuals and can cause lower gastrointestinal bleeding (LGIB), lightheadedness, and syncope.It can be associated with Aortic Stenosis.
* Other options:
 
  • Early stage carcinoma colon: Less likely due to negative stool occult blood test and absence of weight loss.
  • Sigmoid diverticulitis: Less likely due to the absence of recent weight loss history.
  • Microscopic colitis: Less likely as it doesn't typically present with syncope, lightheadedness, or excessive bleeding and pain during defecation.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1370.

questions.text: Which of the following is FNAC unable to detect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Follicular carcinoma
 
  • FNAC (Fine Needle Aspiration Cytology) is unable to detect follicular carcinoma (Option A).
  • Follicular carcinoma of the thyroid cannot be reliably distinguished from follicular adenoma by FNAC alone because it requires histopathological examination of the tumor capsule to confirm invasion.
  • FNAC is useful in detecting other thyroid pathologies such as papillary carcinoma, colloid goiter, and Hashimoto's thyroiditis.
  • FNAC is unable to distinguish between benign and malignant follicular lesions as malignancy is defined by capsular and vascular invasion. Hence, Trucut biopsy is required to confirm malignancy.



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 858.

choices.text: In the temporal region contralateral to the side of pupillary dilatation
In the midline if both pupils are equal or it is not known which side dilated first
In the left temporal region if no localizing sign is found
Refer to higher centre if both pupils are equal or it is not known which side dilated first

questions.text: You have a surgical assignment at CHC. A head injury patient presents to you with rapidly declining sensorium and increasing pupil dilatation and fixation. There is no CT scan or neurosurgeon accessible. To urgently reduce the intracranial pressure, you produce a burr hole. Which website will you pick from the list below
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3. In the left temporal region if no localizing sign is found
 
  • This approach aims to relieve pressure on the affected hemisphere of the brain, as indicated by the pupillary findings.
  • Placing the burr hole same side to the dilated pupil helps to address the intracranial pressure and manage the worsening neurological symptoms.
  • The other options do not specifically address the need to correlate the burr hole location with the neurological signs of intracranial pathology observed in the patient.
  • When there is a localizing sign (like dilated and fixed pupil) then you should put burrhole on that side.
  • If both pupils are dilated, Then burrhole on the side of the pupil which dilated first.
  • If you do not know which side dilated first, then put burrhole on the left side as left side is dominant lobe in most of the people.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 365.

questions.text: All of the following pathological lesions given below are premalignant with the exception of
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Crohn's disease
 
  • Crohn’s disease is a chronic inflammatory condition that primarily affects the gastrointestinal tract, but it is not typically associated with premalignant changes.
  • It can lead to complications such as strictures and fistulas but does not have a direct premalignant potential like the other conditions listed.
  • The other conditions—ulcerative colitis, Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, and Barrett’s esophagus—are associated with an increased risk of developing malignancies such as colorectal cancer and esophageal adenocarcinoma, respectively.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 671, 1268.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman has right iliac fossa pain that is dull and painful. Upon examination, a tumour (mass) in the right iliac fossa could be felt and there was a noticeable gross pallor. Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Carcinoma ascending colon
 
  • In a 58-year-old woman with right iliac fossa pain, a tumor palpable in the region, and noticeable gross pallor, the most likely diagnosis is carcinoma of the ascending colon (Option D).
  • Right-sided colonic tumors, particularly in the ascending colon, can present with nonspecific symptoms such as abdominal pain and weight loss. This patient
  • The palpable mass and gross pallor could be indicative of an advanced stage of colon cancer.
  • Further investigations, such as colonoscopy and imaging studies, would be required to confirm the diagnosis.



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1358.

questions.text: What is the preferred investigation for "acute appendicitis"  in children?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Ultrasound
 
  • The preferred investigation for acute appendicitis in children is an ultrasound (Option B).
  • Ultrasound is non-invasive, readily available, and does not involve ionizing radiation, making it the imaging modality of choice for pediatric patients.
  • It is highly accurate in diagnosing acute appendicitis, with sensitivity and specificity approaching or even exceeding that of CT scan.
  • Ultrasound findings of acute appendicitis:
    • Non-compressible, dilated appendix
    • Thickened appendix wall
    • Presence of appendicolith (fecalith)
    • Peri-appendiceal fluid collection
    • Hypoechoic (dark) appearance of the appendix
* Signs seen in acute appendicitis:


Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1339.

choices.text: Most common mesenchymal tumour of gastrointestinal tract
ALK gene mutation is seen in most of the cases

questions.text: Select the option that is not true about Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumour (GIST).
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) ALK gene mutation is seen in most of the cases
 
  • GIST is not associated with ALK (Anaplastic Lymphoma Kinase) gene mutations. They are associated with KIT gene mutations. 
  • GISTs typically originate from the interstitial cells of Cajal, which are specialized cells in the gastrointestinal tract involved in regulating gut motility.
  • They are the most common mesenchymal tumor of the gastrointestinal tract, and the prognosis can depend on factors such as tumor size, mitotic rate, and presence of metastasis.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 778.

choices.text: Informing The National Commission for the Protection of Child Rights.
Inform the police before starting the treatment

questions.text: A female with a history of suspected child abuse was brought to the emergency room with acute perineal hemorrhage. What should be the primary management aspect?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1. Airway Maintenance

Even in medicolegal situations, saving the patient's life by following ATLS's ABCs (Airway/Breathing/Circulation) is more crucial than alerting the police.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 355.

questions.text: Select the ideal time for the repair of cleft palate.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: 9-12 months
 
  • The ideal time for the repair of cleft palate is between 9-12 months of age (Option A).
  • Repairing the cleft palate at this age allows for optimal speech development.
  • By repairing the palate early, it promotes proper articulation and reduces the risk of speech abnormalities.
  • Additionally, early repair helps improve feeding and prevents complications such as recurrent otitis media.



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 745.

questions.text: Pick the one that is not seen in tuberous sclerosis.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Ependymoma
 
  • Ependymoma (Option D) is not typically seen in tuberous sclerosis.
  • Tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC) is an autosomal-dominant genetic disorder affecting the differentiation, proliferation, and migration of cells early in development, resulting in a variety of hamartomatous lesions that may affect virtually every organ system of the body. Occurs due to mutations in TSC1 (9q34) & TSC2 (16p13)
  • Common brain lesions seen in tuberous sclerosis include giant cell astrocytoma, subependymal nodules, and white matter lesions.
  • Ependymomas are not specifically associated with tuberous sclerosis but can occur independently.





Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1856.

questions.text: What is molecular classification of breast cancer based on?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Gene expression profiling
 
  • The molecular classification of breast cancer is based on gene expression profiling (Option D).
  • Gene expression profiling involves analyzing the activity of thousands of genes in a tumor sample to classify breast cancer into distinct molecular subtypes.
  • This classification system helps guide treatment decisions and predict prognosis.
  • The most commonly used molecular classification is the PAM50 gene panel, which identifies subtypes such as Luminal A, Luminal B, HER2-enriched, and Basal-like (Triple-negative) breast cancer.

Fig: Molecular classification of breast cancer

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 931.

questions.text: What condition of the following is does not results in evisceration?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Congenital umbilical hernia
  • Evisceration typically involves the protrusion of internal organs through an opening, and while the other conditions (urachal fistula, gastroschisis, and patent vitellointestinal duct) are associated with such abnormalities.
  • A congenital umbilical hernia generally involves a defect in the abdominal wall but does not necessarily imply evisceration.
Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 202.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man with a fever has a history of recurrent ureteric calculi. The right side of the kidney was removed. Histology shows 
  • Tubular thyroidization (filled with colloid casts), tubular atrophy
  • Interstitial fibrosis and inflammation (intense diffuse lymphoplasmacytic inflammatory infiltrate with germinal centers).
What is the diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Recurrent ureteric stones may cause recurrent pyelonephritis.
Tubular hybridization, tubular atrophy, Interstitial fibrosis and inflammation all point toward Chronic pyelonephritis. 
The given image below shows the above mentioned histopathology features of chronic pyelonephritis


Fig: HPE of Chronic Pyelonephritis

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1470.

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl has a slow onset soft, uncomfortable swelling on the back of her leg. Without any significant arterial feeder, colour Doppler revealed several venous channels. Except for________, all of the following are employed as liquid embolizing agents
questions.solution:
Except for absolute alcohol, all of the other options (polyvinyl alcohol, sodium tetradecyl sulfate, and cyanoacrylate) are employed as liquid embolizing agents for treating venous malformations or varices.
Absolute alcohol is used as a sclerosing agent rather than a liquid embolic agent in such cases.

Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 228.

questions.text: The next step in the evaluation for a newborn at 48 hours after birth who has a history of not passing meconium is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Lower GI study

Delayed Passage of meconium can occur due to various causes like :
  1. Prematurity
  2.  Sepsis
  3. respiratory distress
  4. Gastrointestinal obstruction
The next step in the evaluation for a newborn at 48 hours after birth who has a history of not passing meconium is a lower GI study. This helps assess for potential causes such as intestinal obstruction or Hirschsprung disease.

Option 1 and 2 are specific tests for the diagnosis of cystic fibrosis
Option 4 Manometry is done to assess the smooth muscle tone of the GI tract.

Some important points to remember in case of CF are
  • AR disorder
  • CFTR gene mutation – located on Chr 7q. [ delta F 508 – deletion of phenylalanine is most common mutation]
  • Mucoviscidosis as Cl- ions cannot enter into the lumen leading to thick secretions
  • Symptoms in newborns may include:
Delayed growth
Failure to gain weight normally during childhood
No bowel movements in first 24 to 48 hours of life
Salty-tasting skin
 
  • Diagnostic criteria :
  1. Presence of typical clinical features
  2. History of CF in a sibling
  3. Positive newborn screening test – immunoreactive trypsin test
If any 1 of the above is present, CF should be confirmed with lab tests
  1. 2 elevated sweat chloride concentrations
  2. Identification if 2 CF mutations
  3. Abnormal transepithelial nasal potential difference
If any 1 lab test is positive, diagnosis of CF is made.
  • Management
  1. Antibiotics – Amoxiclav
  2. Mucolytics
  3. CFTR modulators – ivacaftor, lumacaftor, tezacaftor.


Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page No 280,281

questions.text: Of the following vasculitis, which one does not affect adults?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Kawasaki disease
 
  1. Takayasu arteritis: Takayasu arteritis primarily affects large blood vessels, particularly the aorta and its main branches. It is more common in young adults, especially women.
  2. Susac syndrome: Susac syndrome is a rare autoimmune condition characterized by inflammation and damage to small blood vessels in the brain, retina, and inner ear. It typically affects young women, usually between the ages of 20 and 40.
  3. Henoch-Schonlein purpura: Henoch-Schonlein purpura (HSP) is a systemic vasculitis that affects small blood vessels. It commonly occurs in children, although it can also affect adults. It is characterized by purpura (purple spots on the skin), joint pain, abdominal pain, and kidney involvement.
  4. Kawasaki disease: Kawasaki disease primarily affects children, typically those under the age of 5. It involves inflammation of medium-sized blood vessels throughout the body, including the coronary arteries. It is characterized by symptoms such as prolonged high fever, rash, red eyes, swollen lymph nodes, and changes in the extremities.
Therefore, among the options provided, Kawasaki disease is the vasculitis condition that does not typically affect adults.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2816.

questions.text: Ursodeoxycholic acid and steroids were administered to a 3-month-old baby who had a history of passing clay-colored stools and dark yellow urine since one month. Further examination revealed that he had direct bilirubin of 6 mg%. Which of the following tests is most accurate for diagnosing the aforementioned condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: HIDA scan

The most likely diagnosis for an infant passing clay coloured stools and showing conjugated hyperbilirubinemia is Biliary atresia.
For diagnosis of biliary atresia,
  • USG – triangular cord sign
  • HIDA scan – (screening test)will show absent uptake of the radiotracer in the biliary tract
  • Liver biopsy – confirmatory test
  
The above images show triangular cord sign and HIDA scan respectively.

Option 3 and 4 : Liver function tests and CT abdomen are not specific tests.



Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 327

questions.text: Gram-positive bacilli were discovered during a CSF test of a neonate who had meningitis. Which of the following organisms is most likely to be the cause?
questions.solution:
Listeria monocytogenes is a Gram-positive bacillus and a well-known cause of neonatal meningitis. It is typically transmitted vertically from mother to baby during delivery or in utero.

Other options
  1. Streptococcus pneumoniae: Gram-positive cocci (not bacilli), more common in older children and adults.
  2. Hemophilus influenzae: Gram-negative bacillus, typically associated with older children upto 3-5 years after the neonatal period.
  3. Neisseria meningitidis: Gram-negative diplococcus, more common in older children and most common cause in adolescents and adults.


 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 3223-3232

questions.text: A child with nephrotic syndrome develops acute kidney injury (AKI) following an episode of diarrhoea. The serum creatinine is 4.5 mg/dL. Which of the following is least likely to explain the AKI in this setting?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4 - Steroid-induced diabetes
 
  • AKI in Nephrotic Syndrome is multifactorial in origin. It is most often secondary to hypovolemia, nephrotoxic medications, and infections.
  • In the above case, diarrhoeal disease leading to water depletion/hypovolemia (option 2) is the likely cause of AKI. 
  • Excess Furosemide (option 1) leads to diuresis and is usually given to Nephrotic syndrome patients for edema control but since it leads to diuresis and water loss (hypovolemia) - it can also lead to the development of AKI. 
  • Renal vein thrombosis (option 3)- can occur in patients with nephrotic syndrome due to the loss of antithrombin III (ATIII) in the urine, which in turn leads to an increase in hyper-coagulability and can also be an important cause of AKI in a child with Nephrotic Syndrome. 
  • Steroid-induced diabetes is the least likely reason for the development of AKI in Nephrotic Syndrome since Diabetes leads to "Chronic" nephropathy, and very rarely would cause "Acute kidney injury". Development of Diabetes in a child with Nephrotic syndrome secondary to steroid intake too would take time and would NOT be an acute event

Reference - Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 2769-2771,2742

questions.text: An infant who was born with cyanosis and choking on feeding was later found to have a tracheoesophageal fistula and had surgery to repair it. He was brought to you complaining of an expiratory wheeze and a barking cough. Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
The above case shows typical presenting features of Post TEF repair Tracheomalacia.

  • Option 2 : A child with subglottic stenosis will have inspiratory stridor.
  • Option 3 : Croup will have a history of barking or seal-like cough along with fever but wheezing is less likely. 
  • Option 4 : A child with Asthma will have a history of atopy, a family history of asthma, and night time worsening along with wheezing and no barking cough. 



Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 2214

questions.text: Which among the following is concerning if observed on day 10 of life?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia

Direct bilirubin >2mg/dL at any time after birth is considered pathological hyperbilirubinemia.

Physiological jaundice represents the inability of the underdeveloped liver of neonates to handle increased bilirubin production. It starts from 24 hours after birth and lasts till 14 days. This is unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia can be indicative of liver dysfunction or obstruction of the biliary system and is thus concerning if observed on day 10 of life.

 

Option 1 : Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia is normal because of excessive hemolysis after birth and the absence of enzymes to conjugate the elevated levels of bilirubin

Option 3 : Infants lose weight during the first 7 days after birth. Term infants lose 10% of their body weight and preterms lose 15% they regain this lost weight till 10-14 days of life. Thus no weight gain by 10th day is normal

Option 4 : dolls eye reflex also known and oculocephalic reflex appears in neonates soon after birth and persists for life. It is routinely checked by doing the Dolls eye test to assess brain stem function in neonates.



Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page No 168-170

questions.text: A 5 kilogramme, 65 cm-long baby who is 10 months old has a cough and cold. He was discovered to have a respiratory rate of 48 breaths per minute with no cyanosis, retraction, or grunting. There is no previous history of seizures. Which statement regarding this child is accurate?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: No pneumonia, only cough and cold
 
  • As the child is between 2 and 12 months, the cut-off for tachypnea- which in turn directly means Pneumonia, is 50/min.
  • In this case, the child is not tachypneic and cannot be said to be having Pneumonia.
  • The child also doesn't have any danger signs.



Classification of Fast breathing/ Tachypnea:
  • <2 months: >60 breaths/min
  • 2-11 months: > 50 breaths/min
  • 12-59 months: > 40 breaths/min


Reference: Essential Pediatrics by OP Ghai, 9th edition, Page no 380.

choices.text: Ventilation perfusion mismatch because of increased dead space ventilation

questions.text: A child with bronchial asthma who has been diagnosed presents with respiratory distress and a respiratory rate of 48 breaths per minute while speaking only 2 words. After receiving nebulized salbutamol, the patient was able to pronounce a complete sentence, however their Sp02 dropped from 95% to 85%. What explanation might there be?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Ventilation perfusion mismatch because of increased dead space ventilation
 
  • Ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) mismatch occurs when there is an imbalance between the amount of air reaching the alveoli (ventilation) and the blood flow to the alveoli (perfusion).
  • In bronchial asthma, the airways can become narrowed or obstructed, leading to inadequate ventilation of certain lung areas.
  • When salbutamol is administered, it helps to relax the airway smooth muscles and improve airflow, which may cause an increase in dead space ventilation (ventilation without effective perfusion). This can result in a V/Q mismatch and reduced oxygenation.

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 2155

questions.text: A newborn is experiencing bilious vomiting on the first day of life. The initial investigation to be carried out is
questions.solution:
The correct option is (1): Abdominal X-ray

The initial investigation to be carried out in case of bilious vomiting should be an abdominal X-ray (erect). A neonante presenting with Bilious vomiting can have 3 diagnoses which can be differentiated on the basis of X-ray.



Common congenital GI conditions seen in Neonates and differentiating features:





Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 1951

questions.text: Which disease shown is in the karyotype?
questions.solution:
• The karyotype in the picture shows a partial deletion of chromosome 5p.
  • The Cri-du-chat syndrome is caused by a partial deletion of the short arm of chromosome 5.
  • Children that are affected suffer congenital cardiac problems, a cat-like cry, microcephaly, and mental impairment.


 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 3075

questions.text: A newborn with a displaced mediastinum to the right and an enlarged left upper lung lobe is experiencing respiratory difficulties. Which diagnosis is more likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Congenital lobar emphysema
  • Congenital lobar emphysema is a rare congenital condition characterized by overinflation and hyperexpansion of one or more lobes of the lung.
  • It is typically caused by the narrowing or obstruction of the bronchus leading to the affected lobe, resulting in air trapping and overinflation of the lung segment or lobe. This can lead to displacement of the mediastinum towards the opposite side and compression of the unaffected lung.
  • The scenario mentions a displaced mediastinum to the right and an enlarged left upper lung lobe. This finding is consistent with the clinical presentation of congenital lobar emphysema. The respiratory difficulties experienced by the newborn can be attributed to the compression of the unaffected lung and the associated ventilation-perfusion mismatch.
  • While the other conditions listed in the options (Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency, pneumonia, and cystic fibrosis) can also present with respiratory difficulties, the specific features described in the scenario, such as the displaced mediastinum and enlarged left upper lung lobe, are more characteristic of congenital lobar emphysema.






Reference: Demir, Omer Faruk et al. “Congenital lobar emphysema: diagnosis and treatment options.” International journal of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease vol. 14 921-928. 1 May. 2019, doi:10.2147/COPD.S170581. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6507121/

questions.text: A little child was treated with aspirin for a viral infection. The child was taken to the emergency room three days later with altered sensorium and icterus. What biochemical flaw is causing this?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical scenario described above - viral infection treated with aspirin followed by hepatic dysfunction- Reye's syndrome is the most appropriate diagnosis. It occurs in case of administration of aspirin in children with viral infection. Hence, aspirin should be avoided in a child with fever. Reye's syndrome causes widespread mitochondrial dysfunction particularly defective beta-oxidation of fatty acids that takes place in mitochondria.
 


 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 2126,3178,739

questions.text: A person spends a year in bed due to their being hemiplegic. Bone mineral density changes are initially noticed in:
questions.solution:
• Bone mineral density changes due to prolonged immobility are initially noticed in the proximal femur.
  • This area is particularly susceptible to osteoporosis and bone density loss due to disuse and lack of weight-bearing activity.

Reference- Textbook of Orthopedics by John Ebnezar fourth edition Page no  668

questions.text: Based on an X-sunray ray's appearance, an osteosarcoma diagnosis is made in a young patient. This is a result of:
questions.solution:
• The diagnosis of osteosarcoma based on an X-ray appearance in a young patient is primarily a result of a periosteal reaction.
  • Osteosarcoma often presents with a characteristic “sunburst” pattern or Codman’s triangle on radiographs, indicating an aggressive periosteal reaction due to the rapid growth of the tumor.



Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 240

questions.text: Which displacement from the list below is absent from Colle's fracture
questions.solution:
• Volar Tilt is not seen in Colle's fracture.
  • Colle's fracture is fracture at distal end of radius at the Cortico Cancellous junction 
  • It occurs due to fall on out stretched hands with extended wrists.
  • Displacement can result in a characteristic "dinner fork" deformity of the wrist.
  • In Colles' fracture, the volar tilt is usually maintained, and the dorsal displacement is the main characteristic feature.
  • The displacements seen in Colles fracture as follows -
  


Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no112

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy has swelling in the middle of his tibia. A lytic lesion with sclerotic borders was visible on the X-ray. Which diagnosis is more likely?
questions.solution:
• Osteoid osteomas are benign bone-forming tumors that typically occur in children (particularly adolescents).
  • They have a characteristic lucent nidus <1.5 or 2 cm and surrounding osteosclerotic reaction, which classically causes night pain that is relieved by the use of NSAIDs.

       

Osteoid osteoma xray image
  • Fibrous cortical defect is another benign lesion that can present with a lytic lesion on X-ray, but it does not have the characteristic sclerotic border seen in osteoid osteoma.
  • Osteosarcoma is a malignant bone tumor that usually presents with pain and a soft tissue mass.
  • Fibrous dysplasia is a benign bone lesion that can present with a ground-glass appearance on X-ray, but it does not have the characteristic lytic lesion with sclerotic borders seen in osteoid osteoma.


Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 235,236

questions.text: Pick the inflammatory condition has association with HLA-B27 in 90% cases?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Ankylosing spondylitis

Ankylosing spondylitis (AS) is a chronic inflammatory disease that primarily affects the axial skeleton, causing inflammation and progressive stiffness in the spine and sacroiliac joints. HLA-B27 is a specific human leukocyte antigen (HLA) class I gene that is found in approximately 90% of individuals with Ankylosing spondylitis.
 
  • Option 2: Reiter's arthritis (reactive arthritis): Although HLA-B27 is associated with reactive arthritis, the prevalence of HLA-B27 in cases of reactive arthritis is variable and lower than in Ankylosing spondylitis.
  • Option 3: Ormond's disease is a.k.a Idiopathic Retroperitoneal Fibrosis, commonly associated with IgG4 related diseases
  • Option 4: Rheumatoid arthritis: Rheumatoid arthritis is not primarily associated with HLA-B27. Instead, it is associated with another genetic marker called the HLA-DRB1 shared epitope.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2790, 2793.

questions.text: An individual in his 40s describes acutely developing pain and swelling in his left great toe. On X-ray, a phalanx-based lytic lesion with overhanging bony borders and sclerotic margins is visible. The correct diagnosis would be:
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis is gout. 
  • Gout is a crystal arthropathy due to deposition of monosodium urate crystals in and around the joints.
  • Acute gouty arthritis presents with a monoarticular red, inflamed, swollen joint, typically in the lower limb and classically affecting the first metatarsophalangeal joint. 
  • The drug of choice for an acute attack of gout is NSAIDs. 
  • Allopurinol is not given in acute gout. It is rather drug of choice for chronic gout. 

Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 293

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman has several lytic bone lesions, a fractured clavicle, and second and third metatarsal periosteal resorption. Which diagnosis is most likely
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Hyperparathyroidism
 
  • Hyperparathyroidism is a condition characterized by excessive secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH) from the parathyroid glands, leading to increased bone resorption and thus increased levels of calcium in the blood (hypercalcemia). It's classical symptoms is explained by bones, stones, groans and psychiatric overtones. 
  • This can result in various bone abnormalities and manifestations, including osteoporosis, bone pain, fractures, and periosteal resorption.
  • The presence of lytic bone lesions, fractured clavicle, and periosteal resorption of the metatarsals suggests a significant bone pathology.
  • Hyperparathyroidism can cause bone resorption, leading to the development of lytic lesions and increased risk of fractures.
  • Additionally, periosteal resorption is a characteristic finding in hyperparathyroidism, where the outer layer of bone (periosteum) becomes thickened and shows evidence of increased bone remodeling.








Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3175, 3176.

questions.text: Where is skeltal dysplasia invariably seen?
questions.solution:
• Skeletal dysplasia is a genetic disorder that affects the development and growth of bones and cartilage. It is also known as osteochondrodysplasia.
  • This condition can affect any bone in the body and can lead to various physical deformities.
  • Skeletal dysplasia is invariably seen in developmental defects.
  • All the other conditions can lead to bone weakness and dysplasia but not always, hence the best answer is Developmental Defects as it invariably leads to Skeletal Dysplasia.


Reference- Textbook of Orthopedics by John Ebnezar fourth edition Page no 410

questions.text: A father is holding the hands of a child while the child is being spun around. This caused the toddler to start sobbing and forbid his father from touching his elbow. The discovery is:
questions.solution:
• Pulled elbow (also known as nursemaid's elbow) is a subluxation of the radial head into the annular ligament, which usually spontaneously or easily reduces and rarely demonstrates abnormal radiographic features.
  • The child's symptoms may include pain, swelling, and difficulty moving the affected arm.
  • Treatment typically involves gently maneuvering the bone back into place, followed by rest and avoiding any activities that may cause further injury.


Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 105

questions.text: The H-reflex can be used to diagnose
questions.solution:
The H-reflex (or Hoffmann's reflex) is used primarily to diagnose S1 radiculopathy.
 
  • An H-reflex is a spinal reflex that involves both sensory and motor fibers. It's a sensitive test that can be used to assess radiculopathy.
  • During an H-reflex test, the tibial nerve in the popliteal fossa is stimulated to elicit a monosynaptic S1 reflex response.
  • It assesses the integrity of the S1 nerve root by measuring the electrical response of the muscle following stimulation of the sensory nerve.
  • In evaluating radiculopathy, a unilateral absent H reflex or a side-to-side latency difference greater than 2.0 ms supports a diagnosis of an S1 radiculopathy




Reference: Alrowayeh, Hesham N, and Mohamed A Sabbahi. “H-reflex amplitude asymmetry is an earlier sign of nerve root involvement than latency in patients with S1 radiculopathy.” BMC research notes vol. 4 102. 5 Apr. 2011, doi:10.1186/1756-0500-4-102. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3078869/

questions.text: Which of the following medications is not the first line of treatment for a 13-year-old girl's anovulatory irregular uterine bleeding?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is 4. Danazol
Androgens (Danazol) are not recommended, though effective, because of androgenic effects in young girls.

Management of Anovulatory irregular bleeding in Adolescent girls:
  • In an acute episode of bleeding, i.v. Estrogen 25 mg 6-8 hourly will control bleeding in 24-48 hours. Thereafter, Estrogen for 21 days with progestogen added for 10 days for 3-6 cycles will regularise the cycles.
  • In chronic menorrhagia, oral combined pills or cyclical progestogen is the first line of treatment. About 70%-80% responds well.
  • NSAIDs: Mefenamic acid 250-500 mg t.i.d during periods. Naproxen, ibuprofen are also given.
  • Tranexamic acid being an anti-fibrinolytic drug may be beneficial in controlling bleeding



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 139, 140.

questions.text: Studies have demonstrated that the timing of a caesarean section has no impact on prematurity-related problems such IUGR. When should a caesarean section be performed?
questions.solution:
39 weeks
The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) and the National Institutes of Health recommend that nonmedically indicated elective CDs should be performed after 39 weeks’ gestation to reduce neonatal respiratory morbidity and mortality rates.


Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 549.

questions.text: Pick the option that is not an abdominal laparoscopic technique for tubal ligation.
questions.solution:
Essure is a way of hysteroscopic tubal ligation and laproscopic.

 Essure is a metal coil which when placed into each fallopian tube induces fibrosis and blockage.
      




Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 274.

questions.text: A young woman with average height and little to no pubertal development and anosmia can be seen in
questions.solution:
Kallmann's Syndrome
• It is a form of Hypogonadotrophic Hypogonadism (HH).
• Failure of communication between the hypothalamus and thhe anterior pituitary gland.
• Hypothalamic neurons (GNRH neurons) fail to migrate into the hypothalamus during embryonic development.

Clinical Features:
• Puberty failure
• Lack of testicle development in men
• Primary amenorrhea or failure to start menstruation in women
• Poorly defined secondary sexual characteristics
• Infertility
• Cleft palate or other craniofacial defects
• Anosmia or hyposmia

Investigations
• Low serum testosterone
• Low serum estrogens
• Low levels of LH and FSH
• Karyotype
• X-ray
• MRI

Mode of inheritance:
Genetic mutations in the KAL-I gene (X-linked) or as an autosomal dominant or recessive fashion.

Treatment:
Menstruation can be induced with combined estrogen and progestin therapy. Induction of ovulation is successful with exogenous gonadotropins.



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 142, 143.

questions.text: A young female's infertility is caused by a disorder in which various lifestyle components have been identified. Which of the following changes in lifestyle will not have any impact in the management of the particular disorder?
questions.solution:
The lifestyle change that will likely not have any impact in the management of the particular disorder related to infertility is:

Option 3. Vegan diet

  • A vegan diet, while generally healthy, does not specifically target common fertility-related disorders like polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), which often benefit from weight management, physical activity, and dietary changes that regulate insulin levels.
 
  • Weight loss, more exercise, and a low-carbohydrate diet—can directly impact hormonal balance, insulin sensitivity, and ovulatory function, all of which can help improve fertility in conditions like PCOS.
 

Other options:

  1. Weight loss: Reducing excess weight can improve hormonal balance and ovulation in women with PCOS.
  2. More exercise: Regular exercise helps regulate insulin levels, supports weight management, and can enhance fertility.
  3. Low carbohydrate diet: A low-carb diet may improve insulin sensitivity and reduce symptoms of PCOS, which can aid in managing infertility.


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 314-316.

questions.text: Which medication is under Category B (sufficient research in pregnant women has that not established a prenatal risk)?
questions.solution:
Brimonidine is classified as a category B drug.
Timolol/Latanoprost/Dorzolamide all are category C drugs. 

  • The only antiglaucoma medication categorized in Category B is Brimonidine, and all others are in Category C.
  • Most evidence on glaucoma medications in pregnancy comes from single case reports or animal studies with the limitations that these impose.
  • Theoretically, glaucoma medications may damage the fetus; however, they may not have substantial clinical significance with routine dosages and no topical antiglaucoma agents have strong evidence of safety to the fetus based on the human studies
 






Reference: Razeghinejad, M Reza. “Glaucoma medications in pregnancy.” Oman journal of ophthalmology vol. 11,3 (2018): 195-199. doi:10.4103/ojo.OJO_212_2017, URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6219332/

choices.text: Twin pregnancy precludes the use of oxytocin
Amniotomy decreases the need for oxytocin use
Methods of augmentation does not increase the risk of operational management
Associated with a risk of uterine hyper stimulation

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about augmentation of labor?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Methods of augmentation do not increase the risk of operational management

This statement is incorrect because augmentation of labor, especially with interventions like oxytocin or amniotomy, can increase the risk of operational delivery (such as assisted vaginal delivery or cesarean section), particularly if complications arise, such as uterine hyperstimulation or fetal distress.

Other options:

  • Option 1: Twin pregnancy precludes the use of oxytocin – This statement is generally correct as oxytocin is often used cautiously in twin pregnancies due to the increased risk of uterine overstimulation and complications.

  • Option 2: Amniotomy decreases the need for oxytocin use – This is true, as amniotomy can stimulate contractions, potentially reducing the need for additional oxytocin.

  • Option 4: Associated with a risk of uterine hyperstimulation – This is correct. Augmentation with oxytocin carries a risk of uterine hyperstimulation, which can lead to fetal distress.



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 492-494.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used for screening cancers in females?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Office Endometrial aspirate is not a screening but a diagnostic test for cancer endometrium.

  • The sample obtained by aspiration biopsy can be sent for histopathological examination to determine the type of cancer.
  • For women with genetic mutations, ovarian cancer screening using a combination of CA-125 and TVS should be done.

questions.text: Pick the option that is not a type of lichen planus.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Lichen scrofulous
  • Lichen scrofulosorum also known as “tuberculosis cutis lichenoides,” is a rare tuberculid that presents as a lichenoid eruption of minute papules in children and adolescents with tuberculosis.
  • The lesions are usually asymptomatic, closely grouped, skin-colored to reddish-brown papules, often perifollicular, and are mainly found on the abdomen, chest, back, and proximal parts of the limbs.
  • The eruption is usually associated with a strongly positive tuberculin reaction.
There are many variants of lichen planus based on morphology and location.
They are:
  • Oral, nail,
  • Linear, annular
  • Atrophic, hypertrophic
  • Inverse, eruptive, bullous, ulcerative
  • Lichen planus pigmentosus
  • Lichen planopilaris
  • Vulvovaginal, actinic
  • Lichen planus-lupus erythematosus overlap syndrome
  • Lichen planus pemphigoides
Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 27.26

choices.text: Bacterial growth or culture on selective media

questions.text: After engaging in sexual activity with a new partner, a 25-year-old woman who is sexually active complains of purulent discharge and dysuria. The most sensitive diagnostic investigation is:
questions.solution:
• It is a case of sexually transmitted urethritis which can be Gonococcal or Non-gonococcal and NAAT of the first-catch urine is the diagnostic test of choice and is the most sensitive diagnostic test out of the following for the same.
  • NAATs are primarily used to detect Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae.
  • Testing can be performed on urine samples or swabs from the urethra, cervix, or other relevant sites.

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 30.7, 30.13

questions.text: The glans penis of a 23-year-old male complains of recurrent scaly sores. The same spot would always experience it, and it would recover with a light hyperpigmentation. Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Fixed drug eruption
  • Fixed drug eruptions/reactions are characterized by sharply demarcated, dull red to brown lesions.
  • They occur on lips, hands, legs, face, genitalia, and oral mucosa, and can cause a burning sensation.
  • They are usually solitary or few in number and recur at the same location.
  • But, new lesions can occur on different body parts on re-exposure to the offending drug.
  • FDE is a type of delayed hypersensitivity reaction. Paracetamol/NSAIDs are one of the most common drugs causing FDE.
  • NSAIDS most commonly cause in lips and Tetracycline and Cotrimazole generally cause in genitals. 
Other options:
  • Herpes simplex infection can cause similar lesions and is a close differential, but it can occur at any site and does not necessarily recur at the same site.
  • Candidal infection - a common cause of balanoposthitis in children may present in association with or secondary to diaper dermatitis
  • Though genital ulcers are seen in Behcet's, the glans penis is not affected by this disease. Even the urethra is spared.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 118.11

questions.text: A 24-year-old male laments having pimples. Multiple nodules, cysts, and  sinuses were discovered during an examination. What will you do concerning his treatment?
questions.solution:
• The patient is suffering from Severe Acne based on nodulocystic appearance and hence requires Oral Isotretinoin for treatment.
  • Tazarotene is a topical retinoid while acitretin is used in the treatment of psoriasis. 



Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 90.37

questions.text: Panniculus adiposus can be found in
questions.solution:
• Panniculus adiposus is a layer of subcutaneous fat found in the skin of mammals. It is responsible for insulation, protection, and energy storage and is present all over the body.
  • It is not found in Eyelid, nipple,Scrotum(has dartos muscles) or Penis(has colles fascia)
Reference: https://ifaa.unifr.ch/Public/EntryPage/TA98%20Tree/Entity%20TA98%20EN/16.0.03.001%20Entity%20TA98%20EN.htm

questions.text: The picture depicts a 25-year-old woman who has erythematous papules on her face. Excessive perspiration, exposure to the sun, and emotional distress all made the lesions worse. Description fits with:
questions.solution:
The above clinical description with worsening of lesions on excessive perspiration/sun exposure/emotional distress fits with Rosacea. 

Rosacea
1.  It's a centro-facial disease, especially seen on the convexities of the face (cheeks, chin, forehead, and nose).
2. The exact cause of rosacea is not known but may be associated with an abnormal vascular reactivity (exaggerated flushing response to heat, spicy food, alcohol, and stress) without any pharmacological defect.


Reference :Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 91.6

questions.text: The figure depicts a 65-year-old man who has tense blisters and itching on otherwise normal-appearing skin with urticarial plaques. Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
• The above clinical description fits with that of Bullous pemphigoid.
  • Bullous pemphigoid is an subepidermal immunobullous disorder that affects older age groups leading to blisters/ bullae on urticated as well as normal looking skin and associated pruritus.
  • Antibodies are formed against hemidesmosomal proteins [ BP antigen 230 (BPAG1) & BP antigen 180 (BPAG2 Or Type XVII Collagen)]
  • These antibodies cause damage to dermo-epidermal junction leading to a sub-epidermal split in the skin.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 50.10

questions.text: As seen in the image, a male patient has a hypopigmented patch on his back. What further research would be most beneficial in this situation?
questions.solution:
The image shows a patient suffering from Pityriasis versicolor.
 
Pityriasis Versicolor
  1. Pityriasis Versicolor is a disease caused by Malassezia furfur(a fungus)
  2. It shows hypopigmented, scaly, and perifollicular macules in the upper trunk, neck, and upper arms. Hypopigmentation occurs due to synthesis of azealic acid by fungus which is a tyrosinase inhibitors and reduces formation of melanin. Hyperpigmentation also occurs sometimes due to formation of large melanosomes. 
  3. KOH mount shows Short branched hyphae with spores as spaghetti and meatballs appearance


Hence, KOH mount would be the best investigation among the given options.

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 32.11

questions.text: Propofol was used as an intravenous anaesthetic and succinylcholine as a muscle relaxant during an eye operation. Uncomplicated anaesthetic recovery occurred. However, the patient complained of leg pain when walking eight hours following the surgery. Which of the following explanations is the most likely one?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Succinylcholine

The above clinical scenario is suggestive of post operative myalgia caused by repeated muscular contractions due to succinylcholine.
  • Succinylcholine binds to Ach receptor and causes conformational change in the receptor. Lots of ions are conducted rapidly which produces muscular fasciculations. After a few seconds, time gated Na+ channels close leading to blockade of conduction and eventually muscle relaxation.
  • These initial fasciculations cause post-op myalgia. It can be prevented by giving a small dose of NMDR before Sch. This is known as Precurarization.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 379.

questions.text: Which of the following is the preferred breathing circuit for spontaneous ventilation in a 20-year-old patient with spontaneous breathing who is undergoing incision and drainage under general anaesthesia?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Mapleson A
 
  • Mapleson A circuit, also known as the "Magill circuit," is the preferred choice for spontaneous ventilation.
  • It allows the patient to breathe spontaneously during the procedure, providing better control over ventilation and maintaining adequate oxygenation.
  • It has a spring-loaded pop-off valve near the facemask. Gas enters the circuit opposite the side of the patient. It is best for allowing spontaneous breathing but worst for controlled ventilation. 
The efficiency of Mapleson circuits in spontaneous ventilation is A > DFE > CB.
The efficiency of Mapleson circuits in controlled ventilation is DFE > BC > A.
   



Reference: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 611-613.

questions.text: Pick the agent that is used in day care surgery.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Propofol

Here are the indications and side effects of IV Anesthetics



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 410.

questions.text: Select the option that cannot be used for improving oxygenation in ARDS using a ventilator
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: High-frequency ventilation.
 
  • High-frequency oscillatory ventilation is not typically used as a primary mode of ventilation for ARDS.
  • In ARDS, the mainstay of ventilatory management is Low tidal volume ventilation @ 6-8 ml/kg with high PEEP (Positive End-Expiratory Pressure).
  • Low tidal volume ventilation helps reduce lung injury and improve oxygenation by minimizing lung stretch and maintaining alveolar recruitment. High PEEP prevents lung from collapsing. 
  • High-frequency oscillatory ventilation, although used in certain specific cases, is not the standard approach for managing ARDS.
  • Apart from these, prone position, early neuromuscular blockade (to prevent the patient from fighting the ventilator), and use of extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) have also been shown to improve mortality in patients with ARDS. 




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2227-2229

questions.text: Which of the following devices is related with the names Brechner and Bethune?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: End tidal capnography.
 
  • End tidal capnography is a monitoring technique used to measure the partial pressure of carbon dioxide (CO2) at the end of expiration.
  • It provides continuous and real-time information about the patient's ventilation and can help detect changes in the airway or breathing patterns.
  • Brechner and Bethune are known for their contributions to the development and advancement of end tidal capnography as a monitoring tool in anesthesia.
  • End tidal capnography is widely used to ensure proper ventilation, assess the effectiveness of CPR (Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation), and monitor patients under general anesthesia.


Reference: Pattison WJ. End-Tidal Carbon Dioxide Levels in the Early Detection of Air Embolism. Anaesthesia and Intensive Care. 1975;3(1):58-59. doi:10.1177/0310057X7500300111

questions.text: An individual is said to have a retained fragment of glass in his finger after suffering a glass injury to the forefinger. What investigation will you conduct first?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Plain radiograph
The higher density and effective atomic number of glass compared to that of surrounding soft tissue causes it to be visible on plain radiograph irrespective of the amount of lead content. 
USG is not a good investigation in this case, CT scan and MRI are costly and time consuming. 




Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 1066.

questions.text: Which of the following tests should be used to in the initial evaluation of  a recent head injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: NCCT Head.
 
  • The aim of imaging at initial presentation of an acute head trauma patient is to depict the primary injuries and their extent and to determine if the patient is a potential candidate for neurosurgical intervention. 
  • CT is the workhorse of imaging in traumatic brain injury, especially in the acute setting, and is able to identify the majority of injuries at the time of presentation.
  • It is common for multiple injuries to be present simultaneously, such as the combination of cerebral contusions and traumatic subarachnoid, subdural and extradural hemorrhage as well as skull fractures and facial fractures.
  • Benefits of CT in the acute setting over MRI include increased sensitive for detection of fracture, vascular injury, CSF leak, and not needing to assess for MRI safety (particular in the setting of penetrating injury) and mainly it's less time consuming. 

Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 1387.
Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 362.

questions.text: Which of the following approaches to treating post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is the most effective?
questions.solution:
• Both Trauma focussed Cognitive behavioral therapy and Eye movement desensitization and reprocessing have been shown to be efficacious for therapy for the treatment of PTSD.
  • Most meta-analysis/systematic reviews have shown them to have equal efficacy. 
  • The Better answer however would be option (1). CBT is more accessible, and more widely used and the component of eye movement in EMDR has been questioned.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 438, 445.

questions.text: A guy diagnosed with alcohol dependent syndrome is admitted to the hospital by his wife after consuming 120 ml of alcohol each day for the previous 12 years. He consumed alcohol in the morning before admission. Which medication/therapy from the list below needs to be avoided?
questions.solution:
• Correct Option is 2:  DISULFIRAM
  • Disulfiram inhibits the acetaldehyde dehydrogenase enzyme thereby increasing the level of acetaldehyde in the body which causes various unpleasant symptoms like nausea hepatotoxicity etc.
  • Disulfiram is used to condition the patient to abstain from alcohol use. It should not be given until the patient has abstained from alcohol for at least 12-24 hours. A person taking Disulfiram drug should not take alcohol during the treatment as well as 14 days after stopping the drug.
  • Naltrexone  is  used to treat alcohol dependence by reducing the craving for alcohol. It is not contraindicated in this scenario and can be used as a part of the treatment plan.
  • Acamprosate  is  used to reduce the symptoms of alcohol withdrawal and prevent relapse in alcohol dependence. It is not contraindicated in this scenario and can be used as a part of the treatment plan.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 638, 639.

questions.text: What trait is not present in autism?
questions.solution:
• The trait that is not present in autism is "All patients are mentally retarded". Intellectual disability is commonly associated with autism (upto 50% of autistic children have an Intellectual disability) but not all autistic children are mentally retarded.
  • Intelligence levels can vary widely among individuals with autism, and some may even have above-average intelligence.
  • The other three traits mentioned in the question, poor eye contact, impaired language, and abnormal dermatoglyphics (unusual patterns on the skin of the fingers, palms, and soles), are all commonly associated with autism.


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 1153, 1156.
